comments.commentBody:
The advice to use a string of random characters for a password is impractical and ultimately not secure. People cannot remember such passwords, so they write them somewhere, making them vulnerable to discovery.

The right thing to do is to devise complex passwords from phrases and rules that you can easily remember but no one can guess. For example, memorize a meaningful (to you) phrase like, "My sister's cat's name is Riva and she lives in Milwaukee". Your password is the initial letters: MscniRasliM .

Also, to limit your exposure you should avoid using the same password for multiple sensitive systems. If someone hacks your bank and steals the user ids and passwords it's very easy for them to try the same combination at other common sites.

It's a good idea to always show all icons, because it can help you understand how much junk various software companies are running on your computer, slowing you down and compromising your privacy.

I'm not talking about malware; I'm talking about those little snippets that legitimate vendors install, endlessly checking for updates and doing God knows what else.

A windows based pad would be just like windows on a notebook, a big pain in the butt with all the potential virus and worm problems. I have yet to hear of such issues with Apple products. My only issue with Apple is turning on my new iPhone, iPod now needs a new computer as my 8 year old very functional PowerPC based PowerBook is starting to show its age. Works fine but can not support the new intel based OS upgrades needed for the latest Apple products. I am just waiting for a MacBook Pro that has blueray DVD.

What a bunch of whiny-chip on the shoulder- try hard soccer fans to moan about Beckham. The Galaxy have been in a final and semifinal in the past two years. If these Galaxy fans think they would have had a sniff at that level of play w/o Beckham OR that Beckham, by himself, can magically produce a championship they only reveal their soccer ignorance.  When you watch an MLS game in which Beckham plays, the ability he has compared to the rest of the players around him is glaring, even at 35 years old.  Garber is correct, people in tiny town in Denmark know about the MLS and the LA Galaxy, so the thanklessRiot Squaders and Try hard "Supporters" will reap the benefits of Beckham's Galaxy presence for years to come. The Galaxy games I've attended (including the one which Beckham jumped the fence to have words with some idiot from one of those "Supporters" clubs in the corner seats) have been populated by many many people happy to get to watch Beckham play through balls to Donovan. I guarantee you're not going to be hearing as many dads telling their sons in the stands to watch the way Beckham's replacement crosses, handles the ball, sees his teammates.  Articles like this make you Wish Becks had just gone to NY instead...

If Johnson's is not a catch how could the interception right before halftime of the Bears Packer playoff game be an interception. Replay officials said it was. After the packer player had the ball going to the ground the ball touches the ground and as he rolls over the ball moves in his hands. How did this ever get interpetted
differently. Oh yes it was because it was the Packers not the Lions against the Bears. Quit trying to justify the call against Detroit. The rule was made for the contact with the ground (Tampa Bay playoff game years ago changed how it is interpretted- they were not the team they wanted to win) Just like last year all of a sudden because Farve doesn't get the ball in overtime there needs to be a new rule. If the Saints would not of got the ball instead there would not be a rule change. Tell me I am wrong there also.

The Knicks used to be younger, and better. Now the Nuggets are. I miss Ray Felton and Wilson Chandler most; wasn't totally sold on Gallo or Mozgov but they had their moments seemed to have potential. Couldn't believe it when I read Felton being included in the trade rumors. Ticks me off to read people citing the drop-off in his shooting as a reason not to care about trading him, he'd brought so much more to the team. Including defense, he was the only defender I can remember getting Kobe to miss a shot when the Lakers were in town. Now the fans have got what they asked for, and much more expensive seats from which to witness the result. I'm guessing Mike D'Antoni will be scapegoated and shown the door next.

Good of Grant HIll to take the high road.
Keep in mind that Detroit is a place where some prominent city leaders participate in handing out the Sambo Award. This award is given to black people who have "sold out the black race." One recepient in the past has been former NBA star and current mayor Dave Bing.
Jalen has clarified that he was expressing how he felt as a teenager, not how he feels now. I buy that.
However, I was watching Rob Parker (a prominent Detroit sports analyst) on the NBC channel last night and he chose to feed the flames when this topic came up. He implied that Jalen's [Uncle Tom] charge against Duke is a legitmate one. He said that Grant Hill needed to name the inner city players that Duke has recruited.
I was hoping that Drew Parker would say that there is no place in today's America for blacks to be calling other blacks Uncle Toms or using other pejorative language towards them.

Grant is a class act. He is articulate in expressing his views. Exactly how "massa" would have him behave.....;-) And yes, I jest.
My understanding of Jalen Rose´s remarks in the documentary were that they reflected his world view as a teenager and are not particularly how he feels today. I am hoping that most of our prespectives have evolved since our late teens. I respect Grant right to speak his mind, but in my humble opinion, he should be shrugging this off and putting in the right context and perspective. It is Jalen Rose´s view of Grant Hill and Duke as an institution as a teenager and not who Grant Hill is per se. Big difference. It seems obvious to me that Jalen Rose had a chip on his shoulder as a teenager, otherwise he would not have the need to judge Grant Hill or Duke. That Grant hill feels the need to defend himself and Duke against a teenager´s opinion, speaks volumes about Grant Hill, regardless of how eloquent he presents his case.

This response in the Times was unnecessary. Grant feIl for the bait, laid not by Rose but by the media that enjoys playing black people against one another.

Now with respect to the doc comments, I don't subscribe at all to the sentiments behind calling someone an "Uncle Tom" but I understand the emotions felt by Rose as a teenager that stemmed from the unfortunate divide of economic and social standing in Black America. Rose was very self aware and honest to recognize his own difficulty with this issue, though perhaps unwise in expressing it as an adult in the spotlight.
Ownage.

Did Grant Hill watch the program?  It's obvious that Jalen Rose was talking frankly about his feelings when he was playing for Michigan, not now.  How could Hill and so many readers miss the point? Was he just trying to steal the thunder from Rose's sterling performance?

This is a pathetic response from someone I always thought of as a class act. Grant Hill's ignorance of not only the context of Jalen's remarks, but of America's very real history of racial strife and oppression, seem to evidence some truth to the unflattering characterizations attributed to him by Jalen and the film. Fact is, Duke doesn't want Black players who are simply good athletes, but players who the Duke nation will not find "objectionable." That is, players who know how to "behave" : angry, militant types simply are not welcome, regardless of skill level -- or grades. Jalen's description of that fact may not have been very artful, but it also wasn't very far from the truth. . . .  -- Ronald Peden, author of NOTES ON THE STATE OF AMERICA

Look at the stats, injury-wise.  What few hard tackles have taken out what few available Yanks.  It's open season on our boys, and so far only Gooch has manned up and retaliated.  Where is the response?
Can't wait for him to run. This gonna be good.
Reassuring?  To whom?  His corporate elite masters?  Certainly not the bottom 99% that his kind of being working hard to destroy for the past 30 years.

Voters indeeed want a strong hand at the tiller...but not this selfish handed lobbyist with racial attitudes that illustrates America and the South as the good old boys would have her be.

Repubs see running for pres at a great money raising opportunity...and who of them can resist that trough? NONE!

comments.userLocation: Deep in the heart of Texas
comments.commentBody: Yet another Republican candidate the Democrats would love to hate. With each Haley Barbour/Sarah Palin/Mike Huckabee/etc., President Obama's chances for reelection get better and better. Keep 'em coming!

All I can say is WOW.
A lobbyist for President? How deep has this world (USA) sunk.

Haley Barbour is the perfect megalomaniac to accelerate this country's backward gallop by leaps and bounds. He can finish off what little remains of this shattered and broken democracy.

Less for the poor; more for the rich: Haley Barbour in 2012.
"BossHogg" Barbour should attempt to understand the difference between Integration and Segregation before he begins his comedic run for the Presidency.

Welcome to the Corporate States of America. Mississippi is such a shining beacon of governance that I can hardly wait. How can this guy compare himself to Jimmy Carter or Bill Clinton? Barbour, Pawlenty, Newt, Palin, Huckabee, and even Miss American History, Michelle Bachmann. What a bad dream for America this would be.

Barbour Babble:

Let's bring America back to the glory of the 50's: 1950 and 1850

Let him run on his glorious achievements in Mississippi

Let him make the Mississippi Miracle the American Miracle

While I would like to vote for a Democrat in 2012, I would vote for Obama before this guy.

Why anyone would consider Barbour for any elected office is beyond me. He governs a welfare state; he has done little with the roles he has been given. Mostly they are ceremonial. Being a lobbyist is really just a bag man, or delivery person. His racist comments, and he has made many without apology, should automatically bar him from any elected office. But here he is, when we are supposed to be post-racial, whatever that means. The recent articles on the increases in interracial marriages and children in Mississippi make me wonder how any of them could vote for this platform. I guess ignorance keeps him around, after all.
Barbour... Bachmann... Gingrich... some guy named Cain... Palin... Trump... I am beginning to think the GOP's strings are secretly pulled by Letterman, Conan, and Jon Stewart!

As the US becomes more multiracial (even Mississippi), I think Haley Barbour represents the old guard. He will find himself surprisingly out of touch if he runs in 2012. There's no way an electorate would choose him on the heels of Obama. He represents "old boy" and "old school" along with patronage, excess, and pork. How will he explain his state's dismal school performance and underfunding of black schools when many of the whites attend so-called Christian academies? He will have a lot of explaining to do vis a vis "Civil Rights Era wasn't really so bad."
